newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Spain submits plan to compensate Airtel on GSM.
newsitem.headline: Spain submits plan to compensate Airtel on GSM.

text.p: Spanish Development Minister Rafael Arias Salgado said on Thursday that Spain had reached an agreement with mobile phone operator Airtel to compensate it for a licensing fee of 85 billion pesetas.
It said that under the agreement, submitted to the European Commission on Thursday for approval, the Spanish government would oblige Telefonica to charge lower interconnection tariffs to Airtel.

Airtel is a consortium of banks including Banco Central Hispano and Banco Santander and other industrial and telecommunications partners, notably Airtouch Communications Corp and British Telecommunications Plc.

Arias Salgado told reporters after a meeting with European Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert the deal was worth 15 billion pesetas. There were other "unquantified" compensatory measures such as the granting of frequencies to Airtel, he said.
"The Spanish state recognises Airtel's rights which have been quantified in a letter of intent to the Commission," the minister, who is in charge of telecommunications, said.

Van Miert has repeatedly insisted that Telefonica, which was the monopoly mobile phone operator in Spain before a second licence was awarded, pays a similar fee, or that Airtel gets the money back or that it gets compensation for paying the entry fee.

The compensatory measures proposed by Spain failed to match the amount paid by Airtel by 26 billion pesetas. This, said Arias Salgado, was the fee other operators would have to pay when the government grants more licences.
Van Miert did not immediately react to the Spanish offer. -- Brussels newsroom 322 2876841
